awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Software-as-a-Service Customized Machine Translation for Commercial Language Service Providers and Their Clients
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase-II project develops advanced
technology capabilities for constructing and deploying client-adapted
automated language translation systems within commercial settings that are
used by globalizing enterprises and the language service provider companies
(LSPs) that provide translation services to such enterprise clients.  The
developed technology leverages databases of previously-translated material in
order to produce client-adapted high-quality fully-automatic translations for
commercial language service providers (LSPs) and their enterprise clients.
This approach provides a scalable and less-costly solution for
creating and deploying client-specific customized Machine Translation (MT)
engines.  Once deployed, these customized MT systems expand the capabilities
of clients to translate volumes of content that are not feasible to translate
using current methods.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in the impact
that it will have on the broad commercial translation industry.  The
technology developed in the project is likely to significantly reduce barriers
to wide-spread adoption of MT technology by the broad LSP industry and their
enterprise client-base. The 2010 commercial translation market is a $26
billion industry, growing at a healthy pace. Current commercial MT offerings
are expensive and too difficult to deploy for most enterprises and service
providers.  Free web-based translation services serve casual users, but do not
meet the quality and security needs of enterprises. The technology developed
in this project and the cloud-based delivery model support scalable,
easy-to-integrate MT services, which are highly attractive to a broad range of
potential clients.  This approach will support cost-effective content generation into
multiple target languages at a massive scale, a capability that is essential
for globalizing US enterprises in order to compete in the information-rich
market place of the 21st century.

Safaba Translation Solutions is a technology start-up company, spun-out from Carnegie Mellon University’s Language Technologies Institute. Safaba specializes in developing scalable high-performance automated language translation systems for large commercial enterprises.  NSF Phase-I and Phase-II SBIR grants supported the development of Safaba’s core software solution for adapting state-of-the-art Machine Translation (MT) systems using client-specific data. The Phase-II grant also supported the scaling up of our hosted delivery capabilities in order to enable broad-scale commercialization of the technology.

The technological approach that Safaba has developed is designed to create a highly-scalable software infrastructure for building and deploying a large number of customized instances of MT engines, where each instance is an MT system for a specific directional language pair (i.e. English to Spanish), adapted to produce high-quality translations for a specific client. The key to MT customization is human-quality client-specific translation data. The amount of available client-specific data is often very limited and insufficient by itself for developing high-performance data-driven MT systems. Adding large volumes of “generic” (non-client) data dilutes the client data and results in inadequate translation performance. Safaba’s solution to client-specific adaptation is based on multiple adaptation steps and components.  The most recent version of the technology, developed late in the Phase-II project, supports client-specific adaptation within a single-stage MT engine, using multiple dynamic translation and language models. This technology has been demonstrated to be superior in translation quality to Safaba's earlier two-stage approach, and also inherently supports rapid incremental adaptation.

Safaba’s primary commercial offering is a full-service solution implemented as a software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform. The client-adapted MT engines are developed by Safaba expert technical staff on secure Safaba-internal servers. Once completed, these MT engines are migrated and deployed on Safaba’s secure production data servers, where the MT engines respond to remote translation requests for our clients on an ongoing basis in real-time. The Phase-II grant partly supported the significant challenge of streamlining this process and scaling the hosting software infrastructure and delivery capabilities.

Two supplements to the Phase-II grant accelerated the commercial adoption of Safaba's core technology.  A TECP supplement award provided supplemental funding for developing enhanced capabilities that allow select clients to remotely control the process of developing optimized MT engines using Safaba’s software platform and to deploy these MT engines into production.  An AMJAIC supplemental project supported piloting Safaba’s SBIR-funded technology solutions with a globalizing advanced manufacturing enterprise in order to develop automated translation solutions that directly support the ability of advanced manufacturing enterprises to expand their sales and marketing capabilities in foreign markets.

Safaba’s MT technology was validated as superior in translation accuracy and performance to the technology of its main commercial competitors in various contrastive and competitive pilot projects with potential commercial clients. Revenue-generating deployments for several Fortune-500 enterprise clients were completed over the course of the Phase-II award.  These production-grade MT systems translate millions of words per month.  The advanced technology capabilities developed under the Phase-II SBIR grant allowed Safaba to address the requirements for such large-scale client deployments and to establish itself in the enterprise marketplace.
